sections.heading: 11.4 Experimental Investigations and Discussion
sections.text: The developed control schemes have been validated on the gripper system by conducting several experimental studies. In particular, the gripping and releasing testing of a copper wire with the diameter of 300 µm has been implemented to verify the effectiveness of the presented incremental control strategy.

sections.heading: 11.4.1 Controller Setup
sections.text: The scheme of the position control with force monitoring adopts the DSMC control algorithm, and the position/force switching control involves both DSMC and PID algorithms. Table 11.2 shows the control parameters of DSMC position controller and PID force controller, which are tuned by the trial-and-error method via experimental studies. Moreover, a force threshold of f0 = 3.5 mN and a 2.7 s duration of the

sections.text: Concerning the scheme of the position control with force monitoring, the reference trajectories for the position and force tracking are assigned in Fig. 11.8a, b, respectively. sections.heading: 11.4.3 Further Discussion
sections.text: For comparison purpose, the experimental results of the two implemented control schemes are tabulated in Table 11.3, where RMSE describes the steady-state position/force tracking errors. It is observed that both of the two schemes offer a precision positioning without chattering phenomenon. It benefits from the nice tracking capa-

sections.heading: 250 11 Position/Force Switching Control of a Miniature Gripper
11.4 Experimental Investigations and Discussion 251
sections.text:
bility of the DSMC control algorithm in front of piezoelectric nonlinearities. As compared with the first scheme of the position control with force monitoring [21], the second approach of the position/force switching control has reduced the position and force tracking RMSE by 5.6 and 34.2 %, respectively. The accurate force control is vital for some demanding applications such as biological sample handling.
The first method is relatively easy to implement because no force control is applied. However, during the contact phase, an obvious drift phenomenon occurs in the gripping force, as shown in Fig. 11.8b. The drift effect stems from the PSA with a constant voltage applied. As a result, a constant gripping force cannot be maintained exactly. On the contrary, the second control strategy is capable of regulating both the position and gripping force precisely, as indicated in Fig. 11.10. Moreover, because a force control is adopted in the contact phase, the step response as shown in Fig. 11.10b is much quicker than the ramp tracking response as depicted in Fig. 11.8b. Consequently, the second scheme has reduced the overall execution time of the three-phase grasp process by 11 % as compared with the first approach.
In view of the position trajectories as shown in Figs. 11.8a and 11.10a, it is observed that the opening and closing phases are implemented within a large motion range due to a large initial gap between the gripper tips and the copper wire. In addition, the trajectories consist of both rising and falling curves. Hence, the opening and closing phases exhibit a significant hysteretic nonlinearity. By contrast, the contact phase is realized within a smaller gripping range. In such a small motion range, the hysteresis effect is not dominant while the drift phenomenon requires an explicit treatment. Therefore, the advanced DSMC controller is adopted for the hysteresis suppression in the position control during the opening and closing phases. Whereas the force control in the contact phase is realized using the PID control, whose objective is to maintain a desired touch force by alleviating the drift phenomenon. Another reason of using PID controller for the force control lies in that a force response model of the gripper is not needed in that PID is a model-free control technique. Applying DSMC control strategy in force control requires the identification of a force response model, which complicates the practical implementation procedure. On the other hand, the stand-alone PID control is not able to produce a satisfactory suppression of the hysteresis effect in the opening and closing phases. Hence, DSMC instead of PID is employed in the position control regime.
Additionally, the slopes of the position and force trajectories in the closing or opening phases can be calculated to determine the combined stiffness of the gripper tips and grasped object. For instance, similar stiffness values of 1.104 and 1.092 mN/µm are obtained from the opening phase trajectories of the first and second control methods, respectively. The similarity arises from the reason that the same DSMC position control is applied in the opening phase in both of the two methods, hence similar performance is expected.
The fact that satisfactory tracking results in the closing and opening phases have been achieved reveals the robustness property of the implemented DSMC control strategy under the influence of contact force. Moreover, Figs. 11.8 and 11.10 indicate that a smooth transition between the position and force control has been achieved.

sections.heading: 252 11 Position/Force Switching Control of a Miniature Gripper
sections.text:
The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the presented incremental control scheme dedicated to smooth position/force switching control.
It is notable that a velocity of 50µm/s is employed in both closing and opening phases in the gripping operations. Actually, different velocities can be realized in the two phases. Moreover, other trajectory types and velocity values can also be used. Further experiments indicate that a faster positioning velocity of 300µm/s can be implemented with an RMSE less than 0.5 µm.

sections.heading: 11.5 Chapter Summary
sections.text:
This chapter reports on the position and force control of a compliant gripper, which possesses integrated strain-gage position and force sensors. The gripper provides a gripping range of 276 µm along with the position and force sensing resolutions of 0.345 µm and 1.501 mN, respectively. In addition, the gripping range and initial gap between the gripper tips can be adjusted to accommodate different sizes of objects. An incremental-based smooth position/force switching control framework is proposed to demonstrate a grasp-hold-release operation of a copper wire of 300-µm diameter. Furthermore, the reported DSMC control algorithm simplifies the control design and implementation procedures. Experimental results confirm that the presented incremental control scheme makes it easy to realize a smooth transition during the switching control. Moreover, the position/force switching control performs better than the conventional approach of position control with force monitoring, as the former allows an exact delivery of the desired position and contact force.
In view of the promising accuracy for both the position and gripping force regulation of the presented incremental switching controller, it will be employed for handling deformable biological materials in the future. Moreover, an architectural optimization of the gripper structure will be performed to adapt to the manipulation and assembly of more micrometer-sized objects dedicated to industrial automation.
